definition[0]: if a clock or watch ticks, it makes a short repeated sound
definition[1]: to mark a test, list of questions etc with a tick, in order to show that something is correct, to choose something etc
example[1]: Tick the description that best fits you.
example[2]: Just tick the box on your order form.
definition[2]: a mark (✓) written next to an answer, something on a list etc, to show that it is correct or has been dealt with
example[3]: Put a tick in the box if you agree with this statement.
definition[3]: a very small animal like an insect that lives under the skin of other animals and sucks their blood
definition[4]: the short repeated sound that a clock or watch makes every second
example[4]: I’ll be with you in a tick (=soon).
definition[6]: a mark that you put next to an answer to show that it is correct or against an item on a list to show that you have dealt with it
example[6]: Put a tick in the column that applies to you.
definition[7]: if you get something on tick, you arrange to take it now and pay for it later
definition[8]: an occasion when the price of a share, bond etc moves up or down
example[7]: He had the trades done near the close of the trading day on either a plus tick (=a price higher than the previous trade) or a  zero-plus tick (=an unchanged price following upward price movement).
definition[9]: in interest rates, bond prices etc one hundredth of one per cent
example[8]: The price of the December Eurodollar future quickly rose four ticks, from 94.15 to 94.19.
definition[10]: to make a mark next to an answer or something on a list to show that it is correct or has been dealt with
example[9]: Which of the following features do you feel are important when choosing a bed? (Please tick all that apply).
